author: torfbolt
content:
<@203220829473996800> I'm in there too now, thanks for the teku patch :)
One comment: I had to use --beacon.addr="http://localhost:5051", while the docu says --beacon.addr="localhost:5051"

author: protolambda
content: Oh right, it's without http protocol prefix for grpc Prysm, but with for lighthouse and teku

author: donschoe
content: the default teku metrics port is 8008 not 8080

author: donschoe
content: I added two teku bootnodes

author: donschoe
content: https://github.com/goerli/schlesi/commit/2e157f1bedcdd0109212f2c6d7031d944f9c5cd4

author: donschoe
content: but the ENR is shorter than the others

author: donschoe
content: do I need to worry?

author: nishant0
content: I think their bootnodes might not have the `attnets` and `eth2` key in their enrs

author: nishant0
content:
for the purposes of a bootnode it isn't necessary to have those 2 keys in the ENR, so 
it should be fine

author: donschoe
content: ok

author: protolambda
content: <@557201004060213248> I thought I listed 8008 correctly in the eth2stats client readme. Did I miss something? Where should it be 8008?

author: torfbolt
content: <@340345049063882753> Bug is fixed, it runs on my machine now with ipv6 enabled. Although I don't think I actually have ipv6 traffic on the node.

author: torfbolt
content: Does it make sense to test this? Do we have (boot-)nodes with public ipv6 addresses on the network?

author: nishant0
content: all the bootnodes from <@!557201004060213248> are ipv4

author: djrtwo
content: Lodestar syncing 4th epoch of schlesi! Great work  <@545555441518772225> <@203220829473996800> and the rest of the lodestar team!

author: jonny.derp
content:
Can someone identify this node_id on schlesi?

`d1dfa11bafb7520082eca901eb4d72dd50bef67608259ddaa2cb5a0de063b433`

As of a few minutes ago it's ip seemed to switch from a valid global IP to a 192.168 IP.  I have seen this happen other times and I am curious what client it is

author: jonny.derp
content: Also..we should be better about filtering these IP addresses

author: nishant0
content: when you say ip, you mean its enr gets updated again ?

author: jonny.derp
content: ya it went from an 87.18..xxxxx ip address with an seq_no of 309 to this 192.168 with a seq_no of 394

author: jonny.derp
content: i've seen a similar issue on topaz

author: nishant0
content: Afaik, once a public ip is assigned it doesn't go back to a private ip for prysm

author: agemanning
content: This can happen with lighthouse if it is connected to more local ip nodes than external IP nodes

author: jonny.derp
content: fyi, it's using Prysm default ports of 12000 and 13000. I can gather more evidence, but when the node is using a valid public ip, the udp port is 1024

author: agemanning
content: Doesn't sound like lighthouse then

author: jonny.derp
content:
> This can happen with lighthouse if it is connected to more local ip nodes than external IP nodes
<@!498009160982724610> 

ya, i was aware it could happen in lighthouse...i've just never seen it happen in practice

author: jonny.derp
content: <@!476250636548308992> i could provide a csv from what i am seeing on topaz if it's valuable.  i see several examples of it rn.  Gunna go eat dinner...i will investigate more later

author: nishant0
content: ok thanks, it might be a bug with our endpoint predictor in discv5

author: nishant0
content: by right it should only be using external addresses

author: protolambda
content: <@!604062686623432740> just checked the ips of all my nodes, 87.18.xxx doesn't match mine, can rule out half of eth2stats now ðŸ˜‰
